[[Bamako]], [[Mali]]| capacity = 4,000| chairman = | manager = [[Adama Keïta]][http://www.ortm.ml/site/?p=2294 Championnat national : le stade malien passe le réveillon au chaud] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614121358/http://www.ortm.ml/site/?p=2294 |date=2011-06-14 }}| league = [[Malian Première Division]]| season = 2013–14| position = 10th| pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=FFFF00|body1=FFFF00|rightarm1=FFFF00|shorts1=0000FF|socks1=0000FF| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=|body2=|rightarm2=|shorts2=|socks2=| }} '''Jeunesse Sportive Centre Salif Keita''' (JS CSK) is a [[Mali]]an [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Bamako]]. ==History== Founded in 1995, former players include [[Mahamadou Diarra]], [[Cheick Diabaté (footballer)|Cheick Diabaté]] and [[Seydou Keita (footballer)|Seydou Keita]]. The club was founded by Malian football legend [[Salif Keita (footballer)|Salif Keita]] as a training centre for young Malian football players. Playing in the top division in Malian football its home stadium is [[Stade Centre Salif Keita]]. The team's colours are blue and yellow.[http://www.essor.gov.ml/jour/cgi-bin/view_article.pl?id=21108 Championnat national, CSK-Djoliba 0-1 : LA BONNE SÉRIE CONTINUE POUR LES ROUGES]. l'Essor n°16368. 2009-01-21 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Confederation Cup]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[2011 CAF Confederation Cup|2011]] - Preliminary Round *'''[[CAF Cup]]: 1 appearance''' ::1999 - First Round ==Current squad== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=|nat=Mali|name=[[Oumar Séga Mady Kanté]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=|nat=Mali|name=[[Ousmane Berthé]]|pos=MF}} {{Fs mid}} {{Fs player|no=|nat=Mali|name=[[Idrissa Nama Laïco Traoré]]|pos=FW}} {{Fs end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Malien Premiere Division}} [[Category:Football clubs in Mali]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1995]] [[Category:Sport in Bamako]] [[Category:1995 establishments in Mali]] {{Mali-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Jarry Park Stadium | nickname = Stade Parc Jarry | image = | location = [[Montreal]] | coordinates = {{coord|45|31|58|N|73|37|37|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | opened = August 1960 ([[Baseball]]) | closed = September 26, 1976 ([[Baseball]]) | surface = Grass | owner = [[City of Montreal]] | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Montreal Expos]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (1969–1976) | seating_capacity = 3,000 (1960) – 28,456 (1969) | dimensions = '''Left field''' – 340 ft (103 m)
'''Left-centre''' – 368 ft (112 m)
'''Centre field''' – 420 ft (128 m)
'''Right-centre''' – 368 ft (112 m)
'''Right field''' – 340 ft (103 m)
'''Backstop''' – 60 ft (18 m) }} '''Jarry Park Stadium''' ({{lang-fr|Stade Parc Jarry}} {{IPA-fr|stad paʁk ʒaʁi|}}) is a former [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Montreal]], Quebec, Canada, which served as home to the [[Montreal Expos]] (today's [[Washington Nationals]]), [[Major League Baseball]]'s first Canadian franchise, from 1969 to 1976. It served as a temporary home (for eight seasons) until the domed [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]] was finished and made available to the Expos. The ballpark was typically called simply (and incorrectly, since the stadium was built within the larger park) "Jarry Park" or ''Parc Jarry'' within baseball circles. The stadium was host to two [[American football]] [[National Football League]] preseason games in 1969; August 25 ([[Detroit Lions]] vs [[Boston Patriots]]) and September 11 ([[New York Giants]] vs [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]). The stadium originally began as a baseball field in Montreal's north end ([[Villeray, Quebec|Villeray]]) in a public park known as [[Jarry Park]]. The only structure was the small unroofed grandstand behind the home plate and backstop area, with seating for approximately 3,000 people. [[File:Coupe Rogers 2015 @ Montréal ! (19971844064).jpg|thumb|left| 2015, Former Baseball Backstop grandstand evident]] ==History== [[Image:Jarry night.jpg|thumb|left|The scoreboard at Jarry Park Stadium, 1969]] Previous to Jarry Park Stadium, Montreal's main baseball stadium was [[Delorimier Stadium]], longtime home of the [[Montreal Royals]]. The diamond at [[Jarry Park]] had simply hosted youth baseball on a field in the park. However, in early 1960 the [[Montreal Royals]] were dropped by the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] as an affiliate.{{cite web|url=http://sabr.org/bioproj/park/be7dd3d0|title=Jarry Park (Montreal) - Society for American Baseball Research|website=sabr.org|accessdate=21 January 2018}} [[File:Jackie Robinson Montreal Royals jersey.jpg|thumb|Jackie Robinson Montreal Royals jersey]] Looking to improve facilities for a stadium in Montreal, the 3,000 seat Jarry Park Stadium was built, formally opening in August 1960. After the Dodgers ended their affiliation with the Royals, potential new owners of the team had an option on the franchise, with the provision that a suitable ballpark be put in place. Unable to negotiate an agreement to play at aging Delorimier Stadium, the group looked to spacious Jarry Park as the alternate site. The Jarry Park Stadium was built for this reason. However, even after the construction, the Royals franchise relocated to [[Syracuse, New York]] in 1960. When the original baseball field was later approved for the Expos, it was renovated to a park approaching major league standards. Unroofed extensions were built from the original stands to the left and right field corners, a large bleacher section was constructed across left field, and a scoreboard was built behind the right field fence. This work brought the stadium's capacity to 28,500, and the park was approved as the Expos temporary home. ==Features and dimensions== Beyond right field was a pre-existing swimming pool in the city park. Long before the "splash hits" at [[AT&T Park]] in San Francisco and [[PNC Park]] in [[Pittsburgh]], there were occasional "splash hits" here. The first and most famous was a {{convert|495|ft|m|abbr=on}} blast by [[Willie Stargell]] on July 23, 1969—leading locals to call the pool "Willie's pool" (French: ''la piscine de Willie''). One of those was hit by [[Willie McCovey]] during a 6-4 win over the Expos on August 24, 1969. The idea of the swimming pool itself was later replicated in [[Chase Field]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]. The stadium was rather sparse, given that it was intended to be only a temporary home for a maximum of four years. The clubhouses were located along the left field line behind the stands. Due to its orientation, games in April and September frequently started with the setting sun shining right in the faces of first basemen. Eventually, it was decided to delay games until the sun finished setting. It was completely exposed to the elements, which was a particular problem at the beginning and end of the season, given Montreal's long winters. There was a huge gap between the left-field bleachers and the third-base grandstands, resulting in second basemen and shortstops getting buffeted by cold winds early and late in the season. The Expos frequently had to postpone early and late-season games because there was no protection for the fans. Even allowing for its temporary status, the field conditions were among the worst in the majors. Although the centre field distance was posted as 420 feet, it was actually 417 feet to straightaway centre, and 420 feet to the deep left and right centre field corners. ==Montreal Expos== In their first expansion since 1962, [[Major League Baseball]] added four new franchises for the 1969 season. Along with [[San Diego]], [[Seattle]] and [[Kansas City]], [[Montreal]] was granted a [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] franchise. This marked the first time a team was located outside of the United States. Montreal, Quebec, Canada's largest city, had a strong tradition with minor league baseball, as the [[Montreal Royals]] were a long time Dodgers farm team. [[Jackie Robinson]] had played for the Royals in 1946, before his promotion to the Dodgers in 1947, breaking the [[Baseball color line|color barrier]]. Icon [[Roberto Clemente]] was another Montreal Royal player, as were Dodgers legends [[Duke Snider]], [[Don Drysdale]], [[Roy Campanella]] and [[Tommy Lasorda]]. At the time the major league expansion announcement was made, Montreal had just hosted the 1967 [[World's Fair]], called [[Expo '67]], opened a new subway system and submitted (and eventually won) an international bid to host the [[1976 Summer Olympic Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/teams/washington_nationals.shtml|title=Washington Nationals History and Montreal Expos History on Baseball Almanac|first=Geisler Young, LLC -|last=http://www.geisleryoung.com/|website=www.baseball-almanac.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}} Owner [[Charles Bronfman]] called the new franchise the Expos (after the World's Fair) and hired [[Gene Mauch]] as Manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nl/mtlexpos/expos.html|title=Montreal Expos (1969-2004)|website=www.sportsecyclopedia.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}} When the Expos were announced as an expansion franchise in 1967, one condition for placing a MLB franchise in Montreal was that a domed stadium—thought to be a must due to Montreal's harsh winter weather—be in place for the 1972 season. Finding a site for the Expos to play until that time proved to be a challenge. Delorimier Stadium was ruled out because its location made it impossible to expand beyond its 20,000-seat capacity (it was eventually demolished in 1971). Other options were the [[Autostade]] from [[Expo 67]], a fair which had inspired the new club's nickname. However, the city balked at the cost of adding a dome and 12,000 seats, and the [[Canadian Football League]]'s [[Montreal Alouettes]] demanded onerous rent. The Expos were now in a bind—if they did not find another site quickly, the National League would strip Montreal of its franchise and award it to [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], which already had a suitable stadium in place. In August 1968, [[list of mayors of Montreal|Montreal Mayor]] [[Jean Drapeau]] persuaded National League President [[Warren Giles]] to visit Jarry Park (Parc Jarry). Giles liked the site's location—less than a mile from a highway and 200 yards from a commuter railroad. After settling in at Jarry Park Stadium, a strike delayed the original 1972 completion of a domed stadium. Due to further delays and cost overruns, the Expos wound up playing eight seasons in Jarry Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.andrewclem.com/Baseball/JarryPark.html|title=Clem's Baseball ~ Jarry Park|website=www.andrewclem.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}}{{cite book|last=Keri|first=Jonah|title=Up, Up and Away|publisher=[[Random House|Random House Canada]]|location=[[Toronto]]|year=2014|isbn=9780307361356}} After Montreal was selected in 1970 to host the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Summer Olympic Games]], the stadium projects of the baseball team and of the Summer Olympic Games merged. When it became apparent that Olympic Stadium would not be ready in time, the Expos were forced to seek permission from MLB to stay at Jarry Park Stadium for one more season. Further construction delays eventually forced the Expos to repeat the process until Olympic Stadium was finally ready for baseball for the 1977 season. For a time during the 1976–77 offseason, it looked like the Expos would have to open the 1977 season at Jarry Park due to delays in securing a lease at Olympic Stadium; indeed, the Expos began selling 1977 season tickets under the assumption they would have to play at Jarry. However, an agreement was finally reached in early 1977, allowing the Expos to open 1977 at the new Olympic Stadium.Costello, Rory. [http://sabr.org/bioproj/park/477659 Olympic Stadium (Montreal)]. [[Society for American Baseball Research]], 2013. On the field, the Expos finished 52-110 in their first year. They improved over the years, winning over 70 games in 1970, 1971 and 1972 and came close to the .500 mark in both 1973 and 1974. Their most popular player during the Jarry Park era was [[Rusty Staub]], nicknamed "le Grand Orange." Other players of note at Jarry Park were: [[Maury Wills]], [[Willie Davis (baseball)|Willie Davis]], [[Ron Fairly]], [[Carl Morton]], [[Ken Singleton]] and [[Ken Hunt (outfielder)|Ron Hunt]]. Future Hall of Famer [[Gary Carter]] debuted in 1974 at age 20. [[Warren Cromartie]], [[Steve Rogers (baseball)|Steve Rogers]], [[Larry Parrish]], [[Ellis Valentine]] and the great [[Andre Dawson]] were all young Expos who played their debut seasons at Jarry Park.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/WSN/|title=Washington Nationals Team History & Encyclopedia - Baseball-Reference.com|website=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}} [[File:Jarry Park Montreal 1971.jpg|thumb|[[Houston Astros]] pitcher [[Ken Forsch]] warms up at Jarry Park Stadium, 1971.]] ==No-hitter== One Major League [[no-hitter]] was pitched at Jarry Park. On October 2, 1972, in the first game of a doubleheader against the [[New York Mets]], [[Bill Stoneman]] pitched the first MLB no-hitter outside the United States as Montreal won 7-0.{{cite web| title=October 2, 1972 New York Mets at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197210021.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}}{{cite web| title=October 2, 1972 New York Mets at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197210022.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} ==Notable baseball moments at Jarry== [[File:Fairly in 1969.jpg|thumb|Expo Ron Fairly, 1969]] '''1969 Attendance''' Despite Jarry Park Stadium being the smallest venue in Major League Baseball, the Expos drew 1.2 million fans in 1969.{{cite web|url=http://ballparkdigest.com/200904051700/major-league-baseball/visits/jarry-park-montreal-expos-1969-1976|title=Jarry Park / Montreal Expos / 1969-1976|date=5 April 2009|website=ballparkdigest.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}} '''April 14, 1969:''' In the first [[Major League Baseball]] regular season game in Canada, the [[Montreal Expos]] defeated the [[St. Louis Cardinals]], 8–7.{{cite web| title=April 14, 1969 St. Louis Cardinals at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON196904140.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''1970''' Jarry Park served as the home of both a MLB team and a Class AAA team in 1970. The [[Buffalo Bisons]] (Class AAA; [[International League]]) played 13 home games in Jarry Park. '''September 29, 1971:''' Batting against [[Milt Pappas]] of the [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Ron Hunt]] was hit by a pitch for the 50th time during the season. The Expos won, 6-5, on Hunt's game-winning single in the ninth inning.{{cite web| title=September 29, 1971 Chicago Cubs at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197109290.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''May 9, 1972:''' [[Willie Mays]] plays in his final game as a member of the [[San Francisco Giants]]. As a pinch-hitter, he gets a single in the ninth inning of a 7-1 Giants' loss to the Expos.{{cite web| title=May 9, 1972 San Francisco Giants at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197205090.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''September 9, 1973:''' A year and a half following his last appearance as a member of the San Francisco Giants, [[Willie Mays]] plays the final regular season game of his career as the [[New York Mets|Mets]] defeated the Expos, 3-0, despite 13 Montreal hits.{{cite web| title=September 9, 1973 New York Mets at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197309090.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''September 15, 1973:''' A crowd of 34,331 (the largest ever at Jarry Park Stadium) watches the Expos defeat the [[Philadelphia Phillies]], 5-4. [[Bob Bailey (baseball)|Bob Bailey]] singles home [[Ron Woods]] with the winning run in the 10th inning.{{cite web| title=September 15, 1973 Philadelphia Phillies at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197309150.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''September 28, 1974:''' [[Gary Carter]] hits his first major league home run off Phillies' pitcher [[Steve Carlton]]. The Expos win, 3-1.{{cite web| title=September 28, 1974 Philadelphia Phillies at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197409280.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} '''September 26, 1976:''' In the last baseball games played at ''Stade Parc Jarry'', the Phillies won both games of a doubleheader, 4-1 and 2-1 (the second game shortened to seven innings due to rain), over the Expos. The win in the first game gave the Phils' their first [[National League East]] Division title.{{cite web| title=September 26, 1976 Philadelphia Phillies at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197609261.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}}{{cite web| title=September 26, 1976 Philadelphia Phillies at Montreal Expos Box Score and Play by Play |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/MON/MON197609262.shtml |work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]] |accessdate=2009-01-14}} [[File:Stade Jarry.jpg|thumb|Stade Jarry, 2006]] ==The site today: after the Expos== The stadium was used for various civic events in the years after the Expos moved out. The Inter-Montreal soccer team of [[Canadian Professional Soccer League (1983)|Canadian Professional Soccer League]] (CSPL) played at Jarry. Jarry Park Stadium was gradually converted into a tennis stadium, beginning in 1980, with one corner of the court located at the old backstop. The stadium was renamed in honor of [[Pope]] [[Pope John Paul II|John Paul II]] to mark his visit to Montreal and the park on September 11, 1984. The venue was renamed Du Maurier Stadium in 1987. It has since been upgraded and renamed again, most recently as [[IGA Stadium|Stade IGA]]. Today, Jarry Park contains baseball diamonds, soccer, cricket, bocce, basketball and beach volleyball grounds, pitches and zones, swimming pools and playgrounds, a dog run, and two gazebos. In winter a pond is swept to make a skating rink.{{cite web|url=http://www.montreal.com/parks/jarry.html|title=montreal.com - jarry park|website=www.montreal.com|accessdate=21 January 2018}} ==See also== * [[Jarry Park]] * [[IGA Stadium]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.stadeuniprix.com/ Stade Uniprix official site] *[http://www.montreal.com/parks/jarry.html Jarry Park Today] *[http://www.exposhistoricalsociety.org/files/ballparks/jarrypark.html Expos Historical Society: Jarry Park] *[http://www.baseballchronology.com/Baseball/Stadiums/Modern/Montreal_Parc_Jarry.asp Baseball Chronology: Jarry Park] *[http://www.ballparks.com/baseball/national/jarryp.htm Ballparks by Munsey and Suppes: Jarry Park] * Jarry Park Photos: http://digitalballparks.com/National/ParqJarry.html {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Montreal Expos]] | years = 1969–1976 | before = None | after = {{nobr|[[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]]}} }} {{end}} {{clear}} {{Montreal Expos}} {{Temporary and converted baseball parks}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1960]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in Canada]] [[Category:Defunct Major League Baseball venues]] [[Category:Montreal Expos stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues in Montreal]] [[Category:Tennis venues in Canada]] [[Category:Baseball in Montreal]] [[Category:Villeray–Saint-Michel–Parc-Extension]] [[Category:Tennis in Quebec]] [[Category:1960 establishments in Quebec]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Quebec]]

[[Weapon]]s used in the world's [[martial arts]] can be classified either by type of weapon or by the martial arts school using them.
==By weapon type== ===Melee weapons=== *[[List of melee weapons]] **[[Bladed weapon]]s ***[[Sword]]s: see [[Types of swords]] ***[[Knife|Knives]] ***[[Dagger]]s: see [[List of daggers]] ***[[Axe]] ***[[Sickle]] ***[[Kama (weapon)|Kama]] **[[Polearms]] ***[[Halberd]] ***[[Spear]] ***[[Guandao]] ***[[War scythe]] **[[Blunt weapon]]s ***[[Club (weapon)|Clubs]]/[[Mace (bludgeon)|Mace]] ***[[Stick fighting|Stick]]/[[Staff (disambiguation)#Stick|Staff]]

{{Infobox horseraces | surface = Turf | class = Group 2 | horse race = Moonee Valley Gold Cup | image = | caption = | location = [[Moonee Valley Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] | inaugurated = 1883 | last run = | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] | sponsor = [[McCafé]] (2018 | website = | distance = 2,500 metres | track = Left-handed | qualification = Four years old and over | weight = [[Set Weights]] with penalties | purse = [[AUD|$]]500,000 (2018) | bonuses = }} The '''Moonee Valley Gold Cup''' is a registered [[Moonee Valley Racing Club]] [[Group races|Group 2]] [[Thoroughbred]] [[horse race]] for horses aged four-years-old and upwards under [[Set Weights]] with penalties conditions, over a distance of 2,500 metres, held annually at [[Moonee Valley Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] in late October on [[WS Cox Plate]] Day.<ref name="MVGC">{{cite web|url=http://www.progroupracing.com.au/group-races/moonee-valley-racing-club/moonee-valley-cup|title=Winners and Past Results for the Moonee Valley Cup |work = Pro Group Racing Australia|year=2014|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref> Prize money is [[A$]]500,000.
==History==
The event is the last major long distance event to be run before the [[Melbourne Cup]]. Kingston Rule was the only horse to win the Melbourne Cup after winning the Moonee Valley Cup in 1990.<ref name="Gold_Cup">{{cite web|url=http://www.races.com.au/races/group-2/moonee-valley-cup/|title=Moonee Valley Cup |work = www.races.com.au Australia|year=2014|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref> The Moonee Valley Cup has seen several double winners, such as Little Bob in 1891 & 1892, Gladwyn in 1914 and 1915, Gilltown in 1939 and 1940, Valcurl in 1945 and 1946 and Precedence in 2010 and 2013.<ref name="MVGC"/>
[[File:Nightly 1934 Moonee Valley Cup Jockey Maurice McCarten.jpg|thumb|260px|Nightly winning the 1934 Moonee Valley Cup. Jockey: Maurice McCarten]] ===Name=== * 1883–1975 - Moonee Valley Cup * 1976–1979 - Governors Stakes * 1980–1996 - Moonee Valley Cup * 1997–2002 - Grosby Gold Cup * 2003–2010 - Cathay Pacific Gold Cup * 2011–2013 - Drake International Cup * 2014 onwards - Moonee Valley Gold Cup

{{Cleanup|reason=The references need to be consistently filled and formatted|date=November 2012}} {{MedalTableTop | medals = {{MedalSport | Women's [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] }} {{MedalCountry | {{IND}} }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Asian Indoor Athletics Championships]] }} {{MedalBronze | [[2004 Asian Indoor Athletics Championships|2004 Tehran]] | [[2004 Asian Indoor Athletics Championships – Results#Women's 400 meters|400 m]] }} {{MedalBronze | [[2004 Asian Indoor Athletics Championships|2004 Tehran]] | [[2004 Asian Indoor Athletics Championships – Results#Women's 800 meters|800 m]] }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Commonwealth Games]] }} {{MedalSilver | [[2006 Commonwealth Games|2006 Melbourne]] | [[Athletics at the 2006 Commonwealth Games|4 × 400 m relay]] }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Asian Games]] }} {{MedalGold | [[2006 Asian Games|2006 Doha]] | [[Athletics at the 2006 Asian Games – Women's 4 × 400 metres relay|4 × 400 m relay]] }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Asian Indoor Games]] }} {{MedalGold | [[2005 Asian Indoor Games|2005 Pattaya]] | [[Indoor athletics at the 2005 Asian Indoor Games|4 × 400 m relay]] }} {{MedalCompetition | [[South Asian Games]] }} {{MedalGold | [[2006 South Asian Games|2006 Colombo]] | [[Athletics at the 2006 South Asian Games|400 m]] }} {{MedalGold | [[2006 South Asian Games|2006 Colombo]] | [[Athletics at the 2006 South Asian Games|800 m]] }} {{MedalGold | [[2006 South Asian Games|2006 Colombo]] | [[Athletics at the 2006 South Asian Games|4 × 400 m relay]] }} }}
'''Pinki Pramanik''' (born 10 April 1986 in [[Purulia]]) is an [[India]]n [[track and field|track athlete]] who specialises in the [[400 metres]] and [[800 metres]]. Pramanik had success with the national [[4×400 metres relay]] team, winning silver at the [[Athletics at the 2006 Commonwealth Games|2006 Commonwealth Games]], gold at the [[Athletics at the 2006 Asian Games|2006 Asian Games]], and gold at the [[2005 Asian Indoor Games]]. She won three gold medals at the [[2006 South Asian Games]], winning the 400 and 800 m events, as well as the relay.
Her first success was winning two bronze medals at the [[Asian Indoor Athletics Championships]] when she was 17 years old. She was chosen to represent [[Asia]] at the [[IAAF World Cup]]. Domestically, she has won three times at the [[All-India Open National Championships]]. A series of injuries and a car crash meant that she rarely competed after 2007.
==Career== Pramanik made her mark at junior level when she set four junior state records in 2002.<ref>[http://www.telegraphindia.com/1041124/asp/frontpage/story_4042813.asp Pistol pops out of shooting-star athlete's kit]. ''The Telegraph India'' (2004-11-23). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref> she made her world debut at the [[2003 World Youth Championships in Athletics]] where she reached the 800 m semifinals.<ref name=IAAF>[http://www-verio.iaaf.org/athletes/biographies/letter=0/athcode=196685/index.html Paramanik, Pink Biography]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref> she won the 400 m race at the [[All-India Open National Championships]] soon after.<ref name=GBR>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/ind.htm All-India Open National Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref> she set a record at the National Junior Athletics meeting by running 54.92 seconds in the 400 m, although some confusion over whether she was born in 1986 or 1987 dampened proceedings.<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2003/12/22/stories/2003122203001800.htm Pinki Pramanik's efforts to the fore]. ''[[The Hindu]]'' (2003-12-22). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
===International medals=== She stepped up to the senior level the following year and won two bronzes in the 400 m and 800 m races at the [[2004 Asian Indoor Athletics Championships]].<ref name=IAAF /> In late 2004, an incident in which a group of youths planted a gun on her and called police put her career at risk. However, eyewitnesses testified that the youths had harassed her and had placed the gun in her bag; she was released without charge. She took three months off from competition to recover from the stress of the incident.<ref name=Podium>[http://news.oneindia.in/2006/08/27/from-police-custody-to-podium-pinki-primed-for-higher-glory-1156748179.html From police custody to podium, Pinki primed for higher glory]. One India (2006-08-28). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
Another medal came indoors when she took gold as part of the [[4×400 metres relay]] team at the [[Indoor athletics at the 2005 Asian Indoor Games|2005 Asian Indoor Games]] with [[Iyleen Samantha]], [[Santhi Soundarajan]], and [[Mandeep Kaur (athlete)|Mandeep Kaur]].She returned to compete at the All-India Open National Championships, and came away with 400 and 800 m golds.<ref name=GBR /> The [[Athletics at the 2006 Commonwealth Games|2006 Commonwealth Games]] was her first appearance at the world senior level and she performed well, reaching the 800 m semi-finals and recording a personal best of 2:03.83,<ref>[http://www.melbourne2006.com.au/Schedule%20and%20Results/By%20Sport/Athletics/Thu%2023%20Mar/Results/Result%20-%20AT1008C0100002?ScheduleItemID=28966 2006 Melbourne Women's 800m Semifinal 2]. 2006 Commonwealth Games. Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref> and winning a silver medal for India with [[Rajwinder Kaur (athlete)|Rajwinder Kaur]], [[Chitra Soman]], and Manjeet Kaur in the 4×400 m relay.<ref>[http://www.melbourne2006.com.au/Schedule%20and%20Results/By%20Sport/Athletics/Sat%2025%20Mar/Results/Result%20-%20AT1404E0100001?ScheduleItemID=29078 Melbourne 2006 Women's 4x400m Relay Final] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010075828/http://www.melbourne2006.com.au/Schedule%20and%20Results/By%20Sport/Athletics/Sat%2025%20Mar/Results/Result%20-%20AT1404E0100001?ScheduleItemID=29078 |date=2006-10-10 }}. 2006 Commonwealth Games. Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
At [[Bangalore]]'s Asian Grand Prix meeting in May that year she won the 800 m and improved her 400 m personal best, winning in 52.46 seconds.<ref>[http://www.iaaf.org/news/Kind=2/newsId=34754.html Asian Grand Prix – Bangalore]. [[IAAF]] (2006-05-22). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref> A few months later she marked herself out as one of the region's best runners at the [[Athletics at the 2006 South Asian Games|2006 South Asian Games]]: she won the 400 and 800 m gold medals and headed the relay team for a third gold.<ref>Weerawansa, Dinesh (2006-08-25). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/Kind=2/newsId=35989.html South Asian Games – Day 2]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2010-03-04.</ref><ref>Weerawansa, Dinesh (2006-08-26). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/Kind=2/newsId=35991.html South Asian Games – Day 3]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2010-03-04.</ref> However, she was disappointed that she had not improved her time and said that she expected greater competition from the [[Sri Lanka]]n athletes.<ref name=Podium />
She was selected to represent her continent at the [[2006 IAAF World Cup]] and finished in seventh place for [[Asia]] in the 800 m race. She attended her first [[Asian Games]] later that year, competing the 400 m and the relay. She reached the individual final, but just missed out on medal, finishing two hundredths of a second behind [[Japan]]'s [[Asami Tanno]]. Greater success came in the relay: running with [[Sathi Geetha]], Chitra Soman and Manjeet Kaur, the women's team took India's only athletics gold of Games.<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2006/20061213/sports.htm#1 Foursome strikes gold]. ''The Tribune India'' (2006-12-12). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
===Injuries=== A severe foot injury caused Pramanik to miss much of the 2007 season. She had returned to fitness by August and began competing at regional meeting and recorded 11.07 seconds in the [[100 metres]] in [[Kolkata]]. She set her sights on winning at the 2008 Indian Inter-State championships in order to qualify for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. However, she was struck by injury again and missed the championships due to a [[hamstring]] problem.<ref>[http://sports.in.msn.com/othersports/article.aspx?cp-documentid=3566357 Runner Pinky Pramanik seriously injured in road accident]. MSN/PTI (2010-01-24). Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
In early 2010 Pramanik inaugurated a local competition, the Purulia Athletic Championship. On the way home, she collided with another vehicle and suffered deep cuts to her face and knees. Although her condition was not serious, she suffered from much back pain and remained in hospital for further treatment.<ref>[http://www.zeenews.com/news598729.html Pinki shifted to city-based B R Singh Hospital]. Zee News. Retrieved on 2010-03-05.</ref>
=== Doping === In a 2012 interview, Pramanik related that her coaches required her to have regular injections of "Russian medicine," testosterone, to improve her performance.<ref name="OutlookIndia" />
==Sex controversy== In 2012 a rape allegation by Pramanik's female friend led to medical tests to determine her gender. Initial private tests claimed to show her to be male. Pramanik disagreed with these results and police ordered a separate government-led test as part of the trial.<ref>[http://zeenews.india.com/sports/others/gold-medallist-pinki-pramanik-accused-of-being-male-held-for-rape_743839.html Gold medallist Pinki Pramanik accused of being male, held for `rape`]</ref><ref>[http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/sport/others/confirmed-indian-athlete-pinki-pramanik-male-700 Confirmed: Indian athlete Pinki Pramanik is male]</ref> The results at the [[IPGMER and SSKM Hospital|SSKM Government Hospital]] were inconclusive.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-06-26/kolkata/32423789_1_athlete-forensic-department-conduct Pinki's SSKM gender test inconclusive]</ref> The Court then directed a [[chromosome]] pattern test.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-06-29/athletics/32471551_1_judicial-remand-judicial-custody-gender Court directs chromosome pattern test for Pinki Pramanik]</ref> In November 2012, the further medical tests were reported showing Pinki is a "male [[Pseudohermaphroditism|pseudo-hermaphrodite]]".<ref>[http://sports.ndtv.com/othersports/athletics/item/199193-tests-show-athlete-pinki-pramanik-charged-with-rape-is-male Tests show athlete Pinki Pramanik, charged with rape, is male]</ref> However the medical report has revealed that Pramanik is incapable of having penetrative sex.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-14/athletics/35111300_1_pinki-pramanik-medical-experts-medical-report |title=Medical experts doubt Pinki Pramanik can rape |accessdate=2012-11-14 |work=The Times Of India}}</ref>
In response to allegation of rape and gender representation she said in an interview "The girl who brought these allegations was not my partner and we were not in love. She used to live next door on rent with her lover and her five-year-old child. She had taken nude photographs of me and was threatening to make them public. She had been blackmailing me for some time. But to be accused of being male and raping her shocked me. I am not male. I have always been female. I look more male now because, as part of my training to compete in international athletics, I used to be regularly administered testosterone injections like other female participants. I was told that it was necessary to take these and I never questioned whether these were legal or not. I was focused on winning and did whatever I was asked to do by my trainers, who knew what was best for me. But after that, my voice became deeper and I grew more body hair."<ref name="OutlookIndia" >{{cite news |first= Dola |last= Mitra |title= I Am A Female,And Once Loved A Man |url= http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?281677 |accessdate= November 13, 2012 |newspaper= Outlook India (Magazine) |date= July 30, 2012}}</ref> She also said that she was manhandled and kept in a men's cell in jail. According to her, she did not consent to any testing, and was drugged and unconscious for the examination.<ref name="OutlookIndia" />
Claims were made that Avatar Singh, a power broker and husband of [[Jyotirmoyee Sikdar]], one of Bengal's most celebrated athletes and a former CPM MP had been behind an attempt to frame her, in relation to an ongoing dispute regarding land (awarded to her by the West Bengal government for her superlative performance at the South Asian and Asian games in 2006).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-07-14/kolkata/32674719_1_pinki-pramanik-prime-land-asian-games-gold |work=The Times Of India |title=Jyotirmoyee Sikdar's husband asked me to frame Pinki Pramanik: Ex-partner – The Times of India}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} In team [[sport]]s, a '''man of the match'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/man_of_the_match|title=man of the match - definition of man of the match in English - Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025173131/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/man_of_the_match|archivedate=25 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> award is often given to the outstanding player in a particular match. This can be a player from either team, although the player is generally chosen from the winning team.
Some sports have unique traditions regarding these awards, and they are especially sought-after in championship or [[all-star game|all-star]] games. In Australia, the term "[[best and fairest]]" is normally used, both for individual games and season-long awards. In some competitions, particularly in North America, the terms "[[most valuable player]]" (MVP) or "most outstanding player" (MOP) are used. In [[ice hockey]] in North America, three players of the game, called the "[[three stars (ice hockey)|three stars]]", are recognised.
In sports where playoffs are decided by series rather than individual games, such as professional basketball and baseball, MVP awards are commonly given for the series, and in ice hockey's [[National Hockey League|NHL]], for performance in the entire playoffs.
==Association football== In football, the "man of the match" award typically goes to a player on the winning side. Players who score a [[hat-trick]], or [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeepers]] who keep a [[Shutout#Association football|clean sheet]] under pressure often get the award. Hat-trick scorers usually receive the match ball whether or not they are officially named man of the match.
The man of the match is often chosen by a television commentator or a sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/feb/27/sport.comment4|title=Football: The problem with man of the match awards|first=Si|last=Hawkins|date=27 February 2008|website=the Guardian|accessdate=6 May ghg2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301170032/https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/feb/27/sport.comment4|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, not all competitions have an official man of the match award, so sometimes accolades are given by websites or newspapers instead. In the [[Premier League]], for example, a player receives a small black and gold trophy for their man of the match performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/83956|title=How the Premier League's monthly awards work|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204082122/https://www.premierleague.com/news/83956|archivedate=4 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3742900/Premier-League-s-new-man-match-award-yellow-brick-poking-fun-new-design.html|title=Premier League's new man-of-the-match award is a gold coloured brick|author=|date=|website=dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=6 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019220257/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3742900/Premier-League-s-new-man-match-award-yellow-brick-poking-fun-new-design.html|archivedate=19 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[File:Soccer-1490541 960 720.jpg|thumb|Men playing football, also known as soccer.]]
==Australian rules football== In [[Australian rules football]], the player of the game is often referred to as having been the "best on ground" (or "BOG"). Media outlets provide immediate, unofficial recognition that is largely honorary, often on a 5–4–3–2–1 or 3–2–1 voting basis.{{cn|date=March 2018}} Players may receive a [[Tissot]] watch as an award for their "best on ground" performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richmondfc.com.au/video/2016-08-06/round-20-rance-wins-the-tissot|title=Round 20: Rance wins the Tissot - richmondfc.com.au|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019220230/http://www.richmondfc.com.au/video/2016-08-06/round-20-rance-wins-the-tissot|archivedate=19 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Officially, the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] recognises the player of the game as being the player awarded the maximum three votes by umpires in the [[Brownlow Medal]] count at season's end. Exceptions are made during the season for certain reserved games such as the [[Western Derby]], [[The ANZAC Day clash]], [[QClash]], and [[Showdown (AFL)|Showdown]], where medallions are officially rewarded in presentations following the conclusion of the match. On the day of the [[AFL Grand Final]], a player will be awarded the [[Norm Smith Medal]] as being the best on ground voted by an independent panel of [[Australian rules football]] experts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/stats/awards/norm-smith-medal|title=Norm Smith Medal - AFL.com.au|website=afl.com.au|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016135158/http://www.afl.com.au/stats/awards/norm-smith-medal|archivedate=16 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Cricket== {{main article|Player of the Match awards (cricket)}} In cricket, the man of the match award became a regular feature in Test matches in the mid 1980s.<ref name="test motm">{{cite web |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283704.html |title=Records / Test matches / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) /Most player-of-the-match awards |work=ESPN Cricinfo |publisher=ESPN Sports Media |accessdate=2 January 2014 |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303223723/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283704.html |archivedate=3 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The man of the match title is usually awarded to the player whose contribution is seen as the most critical in winning the game.
In one match held on 3 April 1996, the whole team from [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] was awarded the Men of the Match award. It was the first instance when a whole team was awarded it.<ref>{{cite web|title=4th ODI: West Indies v New Zealand at Georgetown, Apr 3, 1996 | Cricket Scorecard | ESPN Cricinfo|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/64524.html|website=ESPN Cricinfo|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=24 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404011441/http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/64524.html|archivedate=4 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In a test match played between 15,16,17,18 January 1999 between South Africa vs West Indies, the whole South African team was awarded man of the match <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63823.html|title=5th Test, West Indies tour of South Africa at Centurion, Jan 15-18 1999 - Match Summary - ESPNCricinfo|website=ESPNcricinfo|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106053428/http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63823.html|archivedate=6 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In Test matches, [[Jacques Kallis]] holds the record for the highest number of awards won, with 23 in 166 matches played.<ref name = "test motm"/> In ODIs, [[Sachin Tendulkar]] holds the record for the highest number of man of the match titles, with 62 awards in 463 matches played.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html |title=Records / One-Day Internationals / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) /Most player-of-the-match awards |work=ESPN Cricinfo |publisher=ESPN Sports Media |accessdate=2 January 2014 |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304055509/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html |archivedate=4 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tendulkar is followed by [[Sanath Jayasuriya]], who, along with [[Ricky Ponting]], also holds the record for the most Man of the Match titles as captain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Records / One-Day Internationals / Individual records (captains, players, umpires) / Most player-of-the-match awards|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902085726/http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283705.html|archivedate=2 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the shortest form of the game, [[T20 International]]s, this record is held by [[Shahid Afridi]], who has won 11 awards in 99 matches.
==Gaelic games==
In the Gaelic games of [[hurling]] and [[Gaelic football]], the "man of the match" ({{Lang-ga|Laoch na hImeartha}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focloir.ie/en/dictionary/ei/man+of+the+match|title=man of the match - Translation to Irish Gaelic with audio pronunciation of translations for man of the match by New English-Irish Dictionary|website=www.focloir.ie|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817205811/http://www.focloir.ie/en/dictionary/ei/man+of+the+match|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>, "hero of the game") is commonly awarded after important games. An unusual example was the [[2008 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship Final]], where the award was given to [[Brian Cody]], the [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] manager, rather than to a player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=100900|title=Bookie pays out on man of the match bets - Hoganstand.com|website=www.hoganstand.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204048/http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=100900|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In the women's sports of [[camogie]] and [[ladies' Gaelic football]], the term "player of the match" ({{Lang-ga|Laoch na hImeartha}}, "hero of the game") is used instead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clarechampion.ie/fiona-scoops-player-of-the-match-award/|title=Fiona scoops player of the match award – The Clare Champion|website=clarechampion.ie|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817223801/http://clarechampion.ie/fiona-scoops-player-of-the-match-award/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/2017/02/14/ul-repeat-ashbourne-supremacy-ucc/ereena-fryday-receives-her-player-of-the-match-award-from-catherine-neary-1222017/|title=Ereena Fryday receives her player of the match award from Catherine Neary 12/2/2017|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204538/http://www.limerickpost.ie/2017/02/14/ul-repeat-ashbourne-supremacy-ucc/ereena-fryday-receives-her-player-of-the-match-award-from-catherine-neary-1222017/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/gaelic-football/shine-hails-impact-of-teen-star-odonoghue-36028640.html|title=Shine hails impact of teen star O'Donoghue - Independent.ie|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2017/0812/896955-dublin-overcome-plucky-waterford-to-reach-final-four/|title=Dublin overcome plucky Waterford to reach final four|first=Jackie|last=Cahill|date=12 August 2017|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204024/https://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/2017/0812/896955-dublin-overcome-plucky-waterford-to-reach-final-four/|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ==Ice hockey== {{main article|Three stars (ice hockey)}} In North American [[ice hockey]], the three players who perform best in the game, often either those who accumulate the most points or outstanding goaltenders, are usually designated the '''Three stars''' of the game: the top-performing player is the ''first star'', and so on. This tradition originated in the 1930s as a promotion for a "Three Star" brand of gasoline.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/columns/top10/hockeygimmicks.html#threestars] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615075333/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/columns/top10/hockeygimmicks.html|date=15 June 2006}}</ref>
However, in international play (and outside North America), the ''three stars'' concept is rarely used. Instead, other leagues may issue awards to one player who performed best in the game.
==Rugby football== Both codes of rugby, [[rugby league]] and [[rugby union]], commonly have man of the match or player of the match awards. In televised or sponsored matches, a commentator or sponsor often decides who gets the award, and it is presented to the winner after the match.
Examples of man of the match awards in professional men's rugby league are the [[Clive Churchill Medal]] in the [[National Rugby League Grand Final]], the [[Karyn Murphy Medal]] in the [[NRL Women's Premiership Grand Final]] the [[Lance Todd Trophy]] in the [[Challenge Cup]] final and the [[Harry Sunderland Trophy]] in the [[Super League Grand Final]].
==College basketball and football== In [[college basketball]] and [[college football]], the two collegiate sports with the most television coverage in the United States, a top player from each team is usually honoured as "players of the game." These athletes usually cannot collect material prizes due to [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] regulations. Instead, television companies broadcasting the game or corporate sponsors will often make donations to the scholarship funds of each school in the names of the winning players.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
In college basketball's Final Four events, a [[NCAA Basketball Tournament Most Outstanding Player|Most Outstanding Player]] award is given, for performance across both the semi-final and championship game. A Most Outstanding Player award is also given for each of the four regionals, based upon performances in the regional semifinals (Sweet Sixteen) and final (Elite Eight).
==Gridiron football== The [[National Football League]] names an MVP for two prominent games on its schedule: * A [[Super Bowl Most Valuable Player Award]] has been awarded at each [[Super Bowl]] (the NFL's championship). * The [[Pro Bowl]] has had an MVP award throughout its existence. The current Pro Bowl MVP format selects one offensive and one defensive player. From 1956–1971, two MVP awards were given, one to a [[skill position]] and the other to a [[lineman (American football)|lineman]] or [[linebacker]]. In 1972, an offensive and defensive MVP were named. From 1973–2012, a single Pro Bowl MVP was chosen.
Individual games typically have an informal player (or players) of the game chosen by the broadcast network covering the game; one prominent example of this phenomenon is the [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day#Game MVPs|Turkey Leg Award, All-Iron Award and Galloping Gobbler]] trophies awarded for games held on [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]].
The [[Canadian Football League]] awards two MVP awards for its championship game, the [[Grey Cup]]. The [[Grey Cup Most Valuable Player]] award is open to all players; the [[Dick Suderman Trophy]] is limited to players with Canadian citizenship or who were raised in Canada since childhood.

'''Point forward''' is a nontraditional position in [[basketball]], with a [[small forward]] - or sometimes a [[Power forward (basketball)|power forward]] or [[combo forward]] - adding the responsibilities of [[point guard]] to his or her play.
== Characteristics == Generally teams employ a point forward when their best playmaker is a [[small forward|forward]]<ref name=guile_10172013/><ref name=frazier_sachare/><ref>{{cite news|last=Windhorst|first=Brian|title=LeBron eyeing 'point power forward' role?|date=September 28, 2012|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/truehoop/miamiheat/post/_/id/15258/heat-eying-point-forward-role-for-lebron|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHJZtkOl?url=http://espn.go.com/blog/truehoop/miamiheat/post/_/id/15258/heat-eying-point-forward-role-for-lebron|archivedate=March 23, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> rather than a guard.<ref name=guile_10172013/> A point forward is typically responsible for bringing the ball up the court and being the primary facilitator on offense,<ref name=halley_07202012>{{cite news|last=Halley|first=Jim|title=Analysts say point forwards are few and far between|date=July 20, 2012|newspaper=USA Today|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/campusrivalry/post/2012/07/analysts-say-point-forwards-are-few-and-far-between/1#.Uy22ZWW9LTo|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH3lupi1?url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/campusrivalry/post/2012/07/analysts-say-point-forwards-are-few-and-far-between/1|archivedate=March 22, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref name=guile_10172013>{{cite news|last=Guile|first=Aaron|title=Aaron Guile: Gordon Hayward — the emerging point forward|date=October 17, 2013|newspaper=Deseret News|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865588571/Aaron-Guile-Gordon-Hayward-2-the-emerging-point-forward.html?pg=all|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH3u0I6A?url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865588571/Aaron-Guile-Gordon-Hayward-2-the-emerging-point-forward.html?pg=all|archivedate=March 22, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref name=frazier_sachare>{{cite book|last1=Frazier|first1=Walt|last2=Sachare|first2=Alex|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Basketball|pages=97–8|publisher=Penguin|year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KcIF8rb7g9MC&lpg=PA97&dq=%22point%20forward%22basketball&pg=PA97#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn= 9780786549894|accessdate=March 22, 2014}}</ref> but may merely direct play once a guard brings the ball up-court.<ref name=eisenberg_08191992>{{cite news|last=Eisenberg|first=John|title=Imaginations soared with the best Bird|date=August 19, 1992|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-08-19/sports/1992232120_1_bird-magic-point-guard|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH5Wp04z?url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-08-19/sports/1992232120_1_bird-magic-point-guard|archivedate=March 22, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref name=smith_07082014>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Sam|title=WHAT WOULD MICHAEL DO? NOT THIS!|date=July 8, 2010|work=NBA.com|url=http://www.nba.com/bulls/news/smith_michael_100708.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH7RrjOC?url=http://www.nba.com/bulls/news/smith_michael_100708.html|archivedate=March 22, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Berkow|first=Ira|title=Court Vision: Unexpected Views on the Lure of Basketball|page=209|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U1o7nptu3fsC&lpg=PA209&ots=TRDDvFb1oG&dq=bird%20%22point%20forward%22%20%22dennis%20johnson%22&pg=PA209#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=March 22, 2014}}</ref>
Assuming the role of point forward may cut down on that player's scoring, as distributing the ball to others decreases shot attempts. Basketball Hall of Fame small forward [[Larry Bird]], a prolific scorer with exceptional passing skills,<ref>{{cite news|last=Bjarkman|first=Peter C.|title=Boston Celtics Encyclopedia|pages=40–1|publisher=Sports Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cbtwpjrpEUsC&lpg=PA122&ots=rcvqwZuuKh&dq=bird%20%22point%20forward%22%20johnson&pg=PA122#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn= 9781582615646|accessdate=March 22, 2014}}</ref> quipped "I'm a point forward now" after his coaches sought him to score less and pass more.<ref>{{cite news|last=Winderman|first=Ira|title=Impact Players? Ask Teams They Control|date=November 26, 1989|newspaper=Sun-Sentinel|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-11-26/sports/8902120265_1_bird-wound-shots-magic-johnson|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH924b9A?url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-11-26/sports/8902120265_1_bird-wound-shots-magic-johnson|archivedate=March 23, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Sam|title=Pro Basketball|date=December 3, 1989|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-12-03/sports/8903150254_1_guard-situation-knicks-jimmy-rodgers|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH9DC3F8?url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-12-03/sports/8903150254_1_guard-situation-knicks-jimmy-rodgers|archivedate=March 23, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
[[Don Nelson]], a coach often associated with the point forward in his [[Nellie Ball]] system,<ref name=winn_03162009>{{cite news|last=Winn|first=Luke|title=From This Point Forward|date=March 16, 2009|magazine=Sports Illustrated|url=http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?expire=&title=Why+isn%27t+the+best+player+on+the+team+with+the+best+record+-+03.16.09+-+SI+Vault&urlID=525948722&action=cpt&partnerID=289881&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%2Fmagazine%2FMAG1153057%2F2%2Findex.htm|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OHKtivkV?url=http://cnnsi.printthis.clickability.com/pt/cpt?expire=&title=Why+isn%27t+the+best+player+on+the+team+with+the+best+record+-+03.16.09+-+SI+Vault&urlID=525948722&action=cpt&partnerID=289881&fb=Y&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsportsillustrated.cnn.com%2Fvault%2Farticle%252|8=|archivedate=March 23, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> used the role when his guards were not strong ball-handlers.<ref name=guile_10172013/> Other coaches have used point forwards to free their guards to score more,<ref name=winn_03162009/> a strategy of increasing importance as the three-point shot has become the sport's primary offensive weapon.
ESPN analyst Dave Telep maintained a point forward needed to be more than merely an adept passer but also had to facilitate the offense for teammates at least half of the time.<ref name=halley_07202012/>{{clarify|What else would he be doing passing deftly to teammates rather than seeking to score?|date=May 2018}}
== Origin of the term == The origin of the term ''point forward'' is cloudy. Two former members of the [[NBA]]'s [[Milwaukee Bucks]] claim to have coined it: Bucks small forward [[Marques Johnson]] maintains he created it during the [[1984 NBA Playoffs|1984 playoffs]] when the team became short on point guards after [[Nate Archibald]] was sidelined with a hamstring injury. When coach [[Don Nelson]] instructed Johnson to run the offense he says he responded, "OK, so instead of a point guard, I'm a point forward".<ref name=aschburner>{{cite news|last=Aschburner|first=Steve|title=LeBron a point forward? Well, he wouldn't be the first|date=December 21, 2010|work=NBA.com|url=http://www.nba.com/2010/news/features/steve_aschburner/12/15/point-forward/index.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/686MWqxoK?url=http://www.nba.com/2010/news/features/steve_aschburner/12/15/point-forward/index.html|archivedate=June 1, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Then-Bucks assistant coach [[Del Harris]] claims he first mentioned the term to Nelson while discussing how to best use [[Paul Pressey]]. Harris says he came up with the term while coaching [[Robert Reid (basketball)|Robert Reid]] with the [[Houston Rockets]]. Harris credits his predecessor as Rockets coach [[Tom Nissalke]]'s use of small forward [[Rick Barry]] as originating the point forward position.<ref name=aschburner/>
== History == Historically, one of the first to fill the role was [[John Johnson (basketball)|John Johnson]], who played it for the 1970's [[Seattle SuperSonics]] alongside two scoring-minded [[guard (basketball)|guards]], [[Gus Williams (basketball)|Gus Williams]] and [[Dennis Johnson]].<ref name=firstused>{{cite web|title= John Johnson: Point Forward|url=http://www.nba.com/sonics/history/johnjohnson.html|publisher=NBA .com|accessdate=2008-04-23}}</ref> During the 1980s [[Milwaukee Bucks]] [[Marques Johnson]] and [[Paul Pressey]] played point forward under coach Don Nelson.<ref name=secondused>{{cite web|title=Basketball U on Swingmen|url=http://www.nba.com/canada/bu_swingmen.html|publisher=NBA .com Canada|accessdate=2007-09-06}}</ref><ref name=thirdused>{{cite web|title=Original point forward|url=http://hoopshype.com/articles/johnson_ferranti.htm|publisher=hoopshype .com|accessdate=2008-08-23}}</ref> [[Larry Bird]], a 6'9" small forward who excelled at both scoring and rebounding in that position was also an exceptional passer and facilitator of others on offense. In the flow of games he often played a point forward role for the great [[Boston Celtics]] teams of the 1980s;<ref>{{cite news|last=Ventre|first=Michael|title=He Will Give Us All a Lift|date=January 30, 1996|newspaper=Daily News|location=Los Angeles|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83902539.html|accessdate=December 7, 2012|quote=A point power forward. Think of it. It will be similar to the days when Dennis Johnson or Danny Ainge brought the ball across midcourt for the Celtics, passed to Larry Bird, and then let him direct the offense.}}{{subscription required}}</ref> the 6'9" [[Magic Johnson|Earvin "Magic" Johnson]], who orchestrated the [[Los Angeles Lakers]]' offense in the 1980s as the team's point guard, moved to a point forward role upon returning {{convert|27|lb|kg}} heavier after his HIV announcement.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meinecke|first=Corky|title=Magic waited too long|date=January 30, 1996|page=5B|newspaper=The News (Boca Raton)|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Av9TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6o0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2662%2C4720575|accessdate=June 1, 2012}}</ref> [[LeBron James]] is considered a point forward as he usually runs the offense and brings the ball up the court.
==See also== *[[Tweener (basketball)|Tweener]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{other uses2|Power play}} {{refimprove|date=October 2015}} "'''Power play'''" is a sporting term used in many various games.
==Temporary numerical advantage in players during a team sport== In several [[team sport]]s, situations arise where following a rules infraction, one team is penalized by having the number of players on the field of play temporarily reduced. The term '''power play''' is commonly applied to the state of advantage the unpenalized team enjoys during this time. Specialized tactics and strategies can apply while a team is on the power play. [[File:Ferris State 5-on-3 power play.JPG|thumb|right|200px|The [[Ferris State Bulldogs men's ice hockey|Ferris State Bulldogs]] on a 5-on-3 power play against the [[Michigan Wolverines men's ice hockey|Michigan Wolverines]].]]
===Ice hockey===
{{Main|Penalty (ice hockey)}}
In [[ice hockey]], a team is said to be on a power play when at least one opposing player is serving a penalty, and the team has a numerical advantage on the ice (whenever both teams have the same number of players on the ice, there is no power play). Up to two players per side may serve in the penalty box, giving a team up to a possible 5-on-3 power play.
There are three types of penalties that can result in a power play for the non-offending team: minor (two minutes), double-minor (four minutes), and major (five minutes). For such penalties, the offending player is ruled off the ice and no substitute for the penalized player is permitted. If a goaltender commits either a minor, a double-minor, or a major penalty, another player who was on the ice at the time of the penalty would serve the penalty instead.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Hockey League|title=2017–18 National Hockey League Official Rules|pages=40–41|url=http://www.nhl.com/nhl/en/v3/ext/rules/2017-2018-NHL-rulebook.pdf|website=nhl.com|publisher=National Hockey League|accessdate=3 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=International Ice Hockey Federation |title=IIHF Official Rulebook 2014–2018 |page=111|url=http://www.iihf.com/fileadmin/user_upload/PDF/Sport/IIHF_Official_Rule_Book_2014-18_Web_V6.pdf |website=iihf.com |publisher=International Ice Hockey Federation |accessdate=3 March 2018}}</ref> A power play resulting from a minor penalty ends if the team with more players on the ice scores. A double-minor penalty is treated as if the player has committed two minor penalties back to back: a goal scored by the team with advantage in the first two minutes only ends the first minor penalty (and the second will start after the game restarts); a goal by the team with advantage in the last two minutes of the penalty will end the power play regardless of whether a goal was scored during the first part of the double-minor penalty. If a player is given a major penalty, a power play occurs, but the power play does not terminate even if the team on the power play scores (except in overtime as this ends the game); a major penalty only ends when five minutes have elapsed or the game has ended. A match penalty results in the offending player being ejected from the game (and the player is subject to possible further suspensions), but is otherwise treated the same as a major penalty.
If a team is still on a power play at the end of a regulation period, or at the end of a playoff overtime period, the power play will continue into the following period. "Misconduct" penalties (10 minutes in duration), and "game misconduct" penalties (offending player is ejected for the balance of the game) allow for substitution of the offending player, so do not result in power plays.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Hockey for Dummies|title=Controlling a Power Play in Hockey|url=http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/controlling-a-power-play-in-hockey.html|accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref> However in practice, misconduct and game misconduct penalties are often assessed in addition to a major or minor penalty.
A goal scored by the short-handed team during a power play is called a short-handed goal; However, a short-handed goal does not affect the power play, the short-handed team must still serve the duration of the minor penalty. If a power play ends without a goal against the shorthanded team, it is said to have ''killed the penalty''. If a team scores on the power play, it is said to have ''converted'' the power play (that is, converted the opportunity into a goal).
During a power play, the shorthanded team may launch the puck to the opposite end of the rink, and play will continue; [[icing (hockey)|icing]] is not called.
In leagues that conduct overtime with fewer than five skaters per side, the concept of the power play still exists, but its application is slightly modified. For example, the NHL uses a 3-on-3 format for overtime in the regular season, with three skaters plus the goaltender. If regulation play ends with a team on the power play, the advantaged team starts overtime with more than three skaters (almost always four, very rarely five). Similarly, if a player is penalized during overtime, the non-penalized team is allowed to play with an extra skater for the duration of the penalty, with two extra skaters if two players on the same team are serving penalties.
===Lacrosse=== In [[box lacrosse]], a power play is very similar to ice hockey, with two-minute minor penalties and five-minute majors. In [[field lacrosse]], a similar type of penalty situation exists, though the duration of the penalty is only 30 seconds for technical fouls, one minute or more for personal fouls, and up to 3 minutes for certain equipment infractions. Depending on the infraction, the penalty may "release" early if a goal is scored by the other team, or may be "non-releasable", meaning the full duration must be served. The term "power play" isn't used in field lacrosse, but called "extra man offense" (EMO) or "man up" for the team fouled and "man down" for the offending team.<ref>{{cite web|title=Extra-man Offence, or the Power Play|url=http://www.insidelacrosse.com/wire.php?id=444|website=insidelacrosse.com|publisher=Inside Lacrosse|accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref>
===Muggle Quidditch=== In [[muggle quidditch|quidditch]], a power play occurs when a member of the opposing team is given a blue, yellow, or red card. A player serving time for a blue card or yellow card must remain in the penalty box for one minute or until the other team scores.<ref name=USQ>{{cite web|title=US Quidditch Rulebook, Eleventh Edition|url=https://www.usquidditch.org/files/USQ_Rulebook_11.pdf|website=usquidditch.org|publisher=United States Quidditch|accessdate=25 June 2018}}</ref> If a player is assessed a red card, that player is ejected from the game and a substitute must remain in the penalty box for two minutes. This two minutes must be served in full, regardless of how many times the opposing team scores during the penalty. A player receiving a second yellow card in the same game is automatically assessed a red card. Blue cards do not stack; a player may be assessed any number of blue cards without being automatically assessed a more severe card.
A team can never have a keeper in the penalty box. If the keeper is sent to the penalty box, the penalized keeper must immediately switch positions with a chaser teammate. If all chasers are already in the penalty box, the penalized keeper must switch with a beater or seeker teammate. If the keeper's penalty results in that team having all of its players in play serving time in the penalty box, that team forfeits the game.<ref name=USQ />
===Analogous concepts not generally referred to as a "power play"=== *In [[water polo]]. a shorter version of the ice hockey or lacrosse penalty situation exists as well. It is referred to as "man up" or "man down". *In [[futsal]] there exists a situation which is essentially a power play. When a player is shown a [[Red card (sports)#Red card|red card]] and is thus ejected from the game, the penalized team must play short-handed for two minutes, similar to ice hockey. If a goal is scored, the team returns to full strength. *In other forms of [[indoor soccer]], usually played in the United States, there also exists a power play situation similar to ice hockey. *In [[indoor American football]], the 1988 proposed [[World Indoor Football League]] had intended to establish a perpetual power play, in which the offense would always have one man more on the field than the defense. *In [[rugby union]], a player who is shown a yellow card is ruled off the field of play for a period of ten minutes (two minutes in the [[rugby sevens|seven-a-side]] variation). The player may not be replaced, their team must play one player short while they are off the field. The temporary sending-off is usually called a "[[Penalty box#Rugby football|sin binning]]". *In [[association football]], a player who is shown a red card (whether or not it is a straight red or a second yellow) is ejected and may not be replaced to the remainder of the game; the team must play with one fewer player.
==Other uses of "power play"==
===Netball=== Several variant formats of [[netball]] introduce the concept of a power play, a designated quarter where all goals scored by a team are worth twice as normal: *In the original [[fastnet (netball)|fastnet]] format, when a team uses it in a quarter, all goals scored by that team are worth twice as normal. This means that if a shooter (Goal Shooter or Goal Attack) scores a goal outside the goal circle, the goal is worth 4 goals instead of 2. It is also possible for both teams to use their power play in the same quarter. *In the current [[fast5]] format, when a team uses it in a quarter, all goals scored by that team are worth twice as normal. A shooter that scores a goal within 3.5 meters from the goal post scores two points instead of one. Four points (instead of two) if the goal was scored at least 3.5 meters away from the goal post but within the goal circle. If the goal was scored from outside of the goal circle (known as a super goal), six points is scored instead of three. The winner of the coin toss chooses which quarter to have this power play and the other team must choose a different quarter for their power play. This prevents both teams from having their power plays in the same quarter.
===Cricket=== {{main|Powerplay (cricket)}} A powerplay is a feature introduced into One Day International (ODI) cricket in 1991 concerning fielding restrictions. It is intended to add to the excitement. In a powerplay, restrictions are applied on the fielding team: only 2 or 3 players are allowed outside the 30-yard circle (which depends upon the type of powerplay). There are two powerplays in an ODI cricket innings starting from 30 October 2012.
===Power Snooker=== In [[Power Snooker]], this arises when a player pots the power ball. This triggers a period of time whereby all points scored are doubled.
===Roller Derby=== Commonly known as a "power jam", a power play occurs in [[roller derby]] when a team's designated scoring skater (jammer) is serving a penalty.
===Curling=== In the [[Mixed_curling#Mixed_doubles|mixed doubles]] version of curling, a rule called a power play was introduced in the 2016-17 season. Each team can exercise the power play in one end per game, only when they have the hammer (throwing the last rock in an end). Instead of positioning the rock in the house on the center line, it is placed to a position straddling the edge of the eight-foot circle, with the back edge of the stone touching the tee line. The opponent's guard stone is place in line with the stone in the house and the hack. The power play cannot be used in an extra end.<ref>[http://www.curling.ca/2016mixeddoubles/about-mixed-doubles-curling/ Mixed Doubles rules], Curling Canada</ref>

'''[[Rugby union]] in [[Burundi]]''' is a minor but growing sport.
==Governing body== The governing body is the Burundi Rugby Federation.
==History== Rugby was first introduced into Burundi in the late 20th century. Burundi was a colony of [[Belgium]] until 1962, and some of the earliest games may have been played by people from there (see [[Rugby union in Belgium]]). Rugby was also being played in other countries in the region - such as [[Rugby union in Tanzania|Tanzania]], [[Rugby union in Uganda|Uganda]] and [[Rugby union in Kenya|Kenya]] - that were British colonies, again, mainly by whites.
In the 1970s and 1980s, rugby in Burundi became better organised. During that period, it was mainly played by Belgian and French ex-patriates in the country.
===Intambwe Rugby Club=== The first formally registered club was the Intambwe Rugby Club or IRC. The clubs first presidents were Stanislas Mandi and Christian Taupiac.
It produced some notable players including Marc Bourgeois, Charles Mugiraneza, "Okume", Bernard Bordes, Patrice Ndindakumana, Lilian Campan, Louis Riboli and Simeon Sahabo.
The IRC played a number of matches, including ones against French, Rwandan and Kenyan teams.
==See also== * [[Burundi national rugby union team]] * [[Confederation of African Rugby]] * [[Africa Cup]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090803114413/http://www.irb.com/unions/union=11000126/index.html IRB Burundi page] * [http://carugby.com/ CAR] * [http://www.irb.com/en/Home/MemberUnionHomePage?UnionID=126 Burundi]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} on IRB.com * [http://www.rugbydata.com/burundi Burundi] on rugbydata.com * [http://carugby.com/news/8/ Burundi scores first ever test victory] *{{fr}} [http://www.lestimbresdurugby.com/Archivesdurugby/Pays/Burundi.htm Archives du Rugby: Burundi]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=April 2017}}
The '''Tendex''' system is a [[basketball]] [[mathematical statistics|mathematical statistical]] [[formula]] that was created by [[sports writer]] Dave Heeren,<ref>[http://www.sonicscentral.com/statsite.html APBRMETRICS CENTRAL.]</ref> in order to determine the playing efficiency of [[basketball]] players.<ref>[http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2005-04-17/sports/0504160377_1_nba-efficiency-rating-roland-ratings-performance The Evolution Of Basketball Statistics.]</ref><ref>[http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/sports/s_514105.html What is Tendex?]</ref><ref>[https://iscoutsports.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/213687307-Tendex iScout Basketball Help Center FAQs Statistics.]</ref> It is generally accepted as the original weighted [[advanced metrics|advanced stat]] formula used in the sport of basketball.<ref>[http://www.nbastuffer.com/component/option,com_glossary/Itemid,0/catid,42/func,view/term,TENDEX/ Player Evaluation Metrics.]</ref>
==Calculation== The Tendex statistical system has 3 different formulas and is calculated as follows:<ref>[http://www.nbastuffer.com/component/option,com_glossary/Itemid,0/catid,42/func,view/term,TENDEX/ The Tendex Formula=.]</ref><ref>[https://iscoutsports.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/213687307-Tendex Tendex.]</ref>
'''Standard Tendex Rating:''' (Tendex raw statistical formula)
*<tt>([[point (basketball)|Points]]) + ([[rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]]) + ([[assist (basketball)|Assists]]) + ([[steals (basketball)|Steals]]) + ([[block (basketball)|Blocks]]) - (Missed [[field goal (basketball)|Field Goals]]) - 0.5 * (Missed [[free throw|Free Throws]]) - ([[turnover (basketball)|Turnovers]]) - ([[personal foul (basketball)|Fouls Committed]]) / ([[minute (basketball)|Minutes Played]]) / (Game Pace (Possessions Per Game, typically ranges from 60 to 75)).</tt>
'''Modified Tendex Rating:''' (Tendex weighted average statistical formula)
*<tt>([[point (basketball)|Points]]) + ([[rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]]) + 1.25 * ([[assist (basketball)|Assists]]) + 1.25 * ([[steals (basketball)|Steals]]) + ([[block (basketball)|Blocks]]) - 1.25 * ([[turnover (basketball)|Turnovers]]) - (Missed [[field goal (basketball)|Field Goals]]) - (Missed [[free throw|Free Throws]] / 2) - ([[personal foul (basketball)|Fouls Committed]] / 2) / ([[minute (basketball)|Minutes Played]]) / (Game Pace (Possessions Per Game, typically ranges from 60 to 75)).</tt>
'''[[Performance Index Rating|European Tendex Rating (Performance Index Rating (PIR))]]:''' ([[EuroLeague]] / [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]])
*<tt>([[point (basketball)|Points]] + [[rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]] + [[assist (basketball)|Assists]] + [[steals (basketball)|Steals]] + [[block (basketball)|Blocks]] + [[personal foul (basketball)|Fouls Drawn]]) - (Missed [[field goal (basketball)|Field Goals]] + Missed [[free throw|Free Throws]] + [[turnover (basketball)|Turnovers]] + [[block (basketball)|Shots Rejected]] + [[personal foul (basketball)|Fouls Committed]]).</tt>
